w:r.w:t: Under the Sustainable development goals (SDG), target number 6 sets an ambition of universal access to clean water and sanitation for all. WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme. (JMP) developed a set of core questions for monitoring water, sanitation and hygiene at a household level, school and health centres. These core questions aimed to monitor SDG 6 target at a global level.

In Sierra Leone, UNICEF Sierra Leone together with Ministry of Water and Sanitation adopted the core household questionnaire to monitor WASH progress at a household level using a total of 26 indicators. Data was collected at a national level and all estimates are expressed as a representative sample of the national population. Immediate results show a very high association of faecal contamination in drinking water with of lack handwashing facilities. 87 % of all households lacked a handwashing facility, out of these, 89% of those have their drinking water contaminated with Escherichia Coli (E. coli).

WHO estimated that 844 million people globally lack access to safe drinking water. Furthermore, roughly 2.4 billion people globally lack proper sanitation facilities. Lack of both water and sanitation facilities contribute to around 700,00 deaths of children in developing countries annually. Death brought about by waterborne diseases. Epidemiological studies and outbreak investigations globally have found a direct association between poor water quality and infectious diarrhea. This causal relationship is not only due to the fact that water is contaminated at the source or during the distribution, but also how water is stored and accessed in households could be a source of contamination. Around 70 percent of these deaths can be prevented if proper measures revolving drinking water are implemented.
Water Quality by popular definition is
The chemical, physical and biological characteristics of water with respect to its designated use

. Water has many uses such as drinking, swimming, agriculture and even industrial use. Designated use of water is bound by legal measures set both globally and nationally to monitor and control water pollutants. These measures are called Water Quality Standards. If the water fails to attain the standards, then it’s contaminated.

One of the ways the quality of drinking water can be contaminated is either through presence of chemical or biological contaminants. Chemical contaminants include Fluoride, Iron, Chlorine(excess), Arsenic, or salts. Biological contaminants include living microorganisms such as protozoa and bacteria. Biological contaminants are more hazardous and pose serious health risks to humans. Of the most popular and hazardous biological contaminants found in drinking water is Escherichia Coli (E. coli).
Acting on water quality data can greatly reduce biological contamination and diseases causing deaths.

In Sierra Leone, less than 40% of households have access to clean, safe drinking water. Faecal contamination, in particular, poses a serious threat to the health of Sierra Leoneans. Nearly 60% of Sierra Leone population use pit toilets as toilets. This makes it easy for most water sources to have a higher risk of contamination due to drainage. Doris Bah, then the National WASH Coordinator, Ministry of Health and Sanitation attributed this situation to lack of appropriate treatment facilities by most service providers. In 2017, a multiple indicator cluster survey (MICS) performed by the Statistics department of Sierra Leone revealed that all water sources, both at the household level and at the source were found to contain 95% of E. coli contamination.

WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for water supply produced a set of standardized questionnaires administered to households and water facilities that monitor 2030 SDG Goal of attaining clean water and sanitation.

Based on core questions developed WHO/UNICEF, Ministry of Water together with UNICEF Sierra Leon adopted the base questionnaires to suit the nations WASH specific needs Data was collected in 12 district and it included a national household mapping and water point mapping on water sources installed and are managed by UNICEF Sierra Leone.

Proportion of population using safely managed drinking water services is defined as the proportion of population using an improved drinking water source which is accessible on premises, available when needed, and free of faecal (and priority chemical) contamination (JMP). An ambitious rung in the JMP in the service level ladder, data aggregated using this approach reveal that approximately 34% of households in Sierra Leone fetch their drinking water from Basic Water source. This is closely followed by 32% that have no service at all. In Western Rural and Kono, 7 in 10 households have their drinking water as unimproved while in Kono, a similar proportion which represent the majority fetch their water from open bodies such as rivers, lakes and irrigation channels (No service at all)

JMP sanitation ladder is used as a guiding principle that compares sanitation and its service levels. This ladder builds on the type of sanitation facility present in the household reinforced with various management practices. A safely managed sanitation facility which is the topmost rung in the service ladder should be located at the premises, not to be shared with other households and excreta produced should either be treated and disposed off in situ, stored temporarily and then emptied and transported to treatment off-site, or transported through a sewer with wastewater and then treated off-site. On the contrary, an unimproved sanitation facility consists a pit latrine that doesn’t have a slab or it’s hanging or a bucket latrine.

Most of the sanitation facilities in Sierra Leone are improved, this is evidence from the bar chart below that illustrates this context. For instance, 88% of sampled households in Kenema had improved sanitation facilities and near similar percentage, (85%) of households in Bo also had improved sanitation facilities. On the contrary, around 5 out of 10 households in Tonkolili had improved sanitation facilities. Below is a comprehensive stacked bar chart that shows the sanitation service levels across districts.

A household will meet the basic criteria of hand washing facility if there is presnece of a handwash facility that is equipped with soap and water and available on premises. It will be limited if a handwashing facility that is on premises, lacks soap and water. 87% of all households lacked a hand washing facility. Districtwise, at least 9 in 10 households in Bo, Bonthe, Moyamba and Pujehun didin’t have one.

Furthermore, presensce or absence of handwashing facility was strongly associated with the feacal contamination of drinking water. To adduce, 84% of all households that lacked a handwashing facility had highest levels of E.coli in their drinking water. 6 out of 10 households are at a risk of contracting water borne diseases. This infers that risk of contamination was is not only dependent on the type of source but other possible confounding factors such as storage of the water, and in this case presence of handwashing equipment
